awd_titl_txt: Modeling Air Source Heat Pump Performance in Cold Climates
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will increase the data available to industry and the general public on the feasibility of the use of air-source heat pumps (ASHPs) in cold climates.

University of Alaska Fairbanks, Bristol Bay Campus will conduct laboratory tests of at least three models of ASHPs to characterize efficiency at different outdoor temperatures and heat loads. The resulting data will be used to create an ASHP performance model that will be used to identify boundary conditions for which savings in fuel are no longer achieved, considering the additional fuel that needs to be burned in a power plant to produce the electricity for the ASHP.  A control strategy for turning the ASHP on and off will be created to save fuel. A long-term model will be developed that estimates the annual savings in fuel achieved by using an ASHP as a supplemental heating system controlled with the developed control strategy. The long-term model may be applied to twelve rural Alaska communities to determine the potential benefit in a variety of real-world conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An air source heat pump (ASHP) is a device that uses a refrigeration cycle to remove heat from the outside air and transfer it into a building. It is an alternative to conventional heat sources that create the heat, often by combustion, inside the building as opposed to transferring it from the outside. An ASHP needs electricity to drive the refrigeration cycle. The electricity is often created by burning fuel in a power plant and a logical question to ask is: How does the amount of fuel that the power plant needs to burn to supply the electricity for the heat pump compare to the amount of fuel that would be needed if the heat was created directly with a combustion heating system in the building?

One of the goals of this project was to help answer this question, particularly in the context of rural Alaska communities, many of which face very high energy costs and other challenges associated with importing fuels to those communities. The answer to the question depends largely on the efficiency of the heat pump, which is described by the Coefficient of Performance (COP). COP expresses how many units of energy in the form of heat are supplied to the building for every unit of electrical energy supplied to the heat pump. In general, the COP decreases with decreasing outdoor temperature, but it also depends on the level of thermal loading. In this project, four different ASHP models were evaluated in a lab utilizing a cold chamber and the COP was characterized as a function of the temperature in the chamber (representing the outdoor temperature) and the level of thermal loading. The data for all four ASHPs was combined and a general model was created that can be used to estimate the COP as a function of the outside temperature and the level of thermal loading. This model not only gives insights on fuel savings with ASHPs, but also helps answer questions regarding sizing and operation of ASHPs.

One particular use for this model is to help determine in which outdoor temperature and thermal load conditions the COP is high enough that savings in fuel are achieved. Consequently, the heat pump can be controlled in a way that it is only on in conditions when fuel savings are achieved and it is off otherwise, which means then the building's primary heating system is covering the thermal load of the building. One of the goals of this project was to perform modeling to determine energy savings for ASHPs in various communities in Alaska if the ASHPs utilize this control strategy. Although the savings vary, it was found that practically all communities in Alaska can achieve some energy savings by utilizing ASHPs if they are used as a supplemental heating system and properly controlled so they are only on in conditions that yield favorable COP.

Aside from disseminating the results of this project through a journal article, conference presentations, and individual discussions with community members, the project findings were also integrated into classes offered by the Sustainable Energy Program at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) Bristol Bay Campus (BBC). UAF BBC is an Alaska Native Serving Institution located in rural Alaska and serves students that are underrepresented in science. Other broader impacts of this project include advancing the use of heat pumps in cold climates and helping reduce the consumption of fossil fuels, which are known to contribute to global societal and environmental problems.
